column1: Kościan [ˈkɔɕt͡ɕan] (German: Kosten) is a town on the Obra canal in west-central Poland
column2: with a population of 23 952 inhabitants as of June 2014. Situated in the Greater Poland Voivodeship (since 1999)
column4: it is the capital of Kościan County.

column1: Polish nobleman Ignacy Wyssogota Zakrzewski was born nearby.
Kościan was founded in the 12th or 13th century
column2: when it was part of the Duchy of Greater Poland of the fragmented Polish realm. It was granted town rights in the second half of the 13th century
column3: which were later confirmed by King Władysław Jagiełło in 1400. From 1332 Kościan was a royal town of Poland. It was a county (powiat) seat in the Poznań Voivodeship in the Greater Poland Province of the Polish Crown. In medieval times the town was an important center of craftwork and formed a German language island in Polish-speaking environs
column4: . In the 15th century Kościan was famous for its cloth production. King Casimir IV Jagiellon granted Kościan cloths the first industrial trademark in the history of Poland. At the time Kościan was the second largest city within historic Greater Poland (behind Poznań).Kościan was captured by the Swedes during the Swedish invasion of Poland (the Swedish Deluge) in 1655
column5: but was soon recaptured by a partisan unit led by Krzysztof Żegocki. The town suffered from further Swedish and Russian invasions in the 18th century
column6: and was annexed by Prussia in the Second Partition of Poland in 1793. The Polish Greater Poland uprising of 1794 began in Kościan. In 1807 the town became part of the short-lived Polish Duchy of Warsaw
column7: before being reannexed by Prussia in 1815
column8: and it was restored to Poland after the country regained independence in 1918.
